required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Study of Avastin (Bevacizumab) in Combination With Herceptin (Trastuzumab)/Docetaxel in Patients With HER2 Positive Metastatic Breast Cancer.
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Open-label Study to Compare the Effect of First-line Treatment With Avastin in Combination With Herceptin/Docetaxel and Herceptin/Docetaxel Alone on Progression-free Survival in Patients With HER2 Positive Locally Recurrent or Metastatic Breast Cancer.

brief_summary.textblock: This 2 arm study will compare the efficacy and safety of Avastin plus Herceptin/docetaxel, versus Herceptin/docetaxel alone, in patients with HER2 positive locally recurrent or metastatic breast cancer who have not received prior chemotherapy for their metastatic disease. Patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either Avastin (15mg/kg iv q3weeks) + Herceptin (8mg/kg iv loading dose and 6mg/kg iv q3weeks maintenance) + docetaxel (100mg/m2 iv q3weeks) or Herceptin + docetaxel alone. The anticipated time on study treatment is until disease progression, and the target sample size is 100-500 individuals.

primary_outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)
primary_outcome.description: PFS was defined as the time from randomization to time of first documented disease progression (unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions) or death, whichever occurred first as assessed by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.0 (RECIST v1.0). Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started. Primary PFS variable was defined based on the investigators' assessments and the statistical conclusions on the primary efficacy endpoint were based on investigator assessed PFS. PFS was estimated using Kaplan-Meier methods.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)
secondary_outcome.description: OS was defined as the time from randomization to the date of death, regardless of the cause of death. OS was estimated using Kaplan-Meier methods.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants With a Best Overall Response (OR) of Confirmed Complete Response (CR) or Partial Response (PR) in Participants With Measurable Disease at Baseline
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)
secondary_outcome.description: Best OR was assessed using RECIST v1.0 criteria. Participants were classified as responders if their best OR was either confirmed CR (disappearance of all target lesions) or confirmed PR (at least a 30% decrease in the sum of the longest diameter [LD] of target lesions, taking as reference the baseline sum LD). Participants without any post-baseline assessments were regarded as non-responders. The 95% CI for the one sample binomial using Pearson-Clopper method.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)
secondary_outcome.description: DR was defined as the time when response (CR or PR per RECIST v1.0) was first documented to the date of disease progression per RECIST v1.0 (unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions) or death. Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)
secondary_outcome.description: TTF was defined as the time between randomization and date of disease progression (per RECIST v1.0; unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions), death, or withdrawal of treatment due to adverse events, withdrawal of informed consent, insufficient therapeutic response, refusal of treatment/failure to co-operate, or failure to return, whichever occurred first. Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started.

secondary_outcome.measure: Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Generic (FACT-G) and Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Breast (FACT-B) Subscale Scores
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Cycles 3, 5, 11, and post progressive disease (PD; 14 to 28 days after disease progression [up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years])
secondary_outcome.description: FACT-G is core questionnaire of Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) measurement system to evaluate quality of life (QoL) in cancer population. FACT-G consisted of 27 questions grouped in 4 domains of general Health-Related QoL (HRQoL): Physical Well-being (PWB), Social/Family Well-Being (SWB), Emotional Well-Being (EWB) and Functional Well-Being (FWB); each ranged from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much). FACT-G ranged between 0-108. Since questions could be reversed coded, as appropriate, before calculating FACT-G, 0 and 108 could be considered worst and best health states. FACT -B is used for assessment of HRQoL in participants with breast cancer. It consists of 36 items, summarized to 5 subscales: 7 items for each physical, functional, social/family; all 3 ranged from 0-28, emotional (6 items) ranged from 0-24, and breast cancer subscale (9 items) ranged from 0-36. All single-item measures ranges from 0-144. High scale score represents a better QoL.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline for FACT-G and FACT-B
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Cycles 3, 5, 11, and post PD (14 to 28 days after disease progression [up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years])
secondary_outcome.description: FACT-G is core questionnaire of Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) measurement system to evaluate quality of life (QoL) in cancer population. FACT-G consisted of 27 questions grouped in 4 domains of general Health-Related QoL (HRQoL): Physical Well-being (PWB), Social/Family Well-Being (SWB), Emotional Well-Being (EWB) and Functional Well-Being (FWB); each ranged from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much). FACT-G ranged between 0-108. Since questions could be reversed coded, as appropriate, before calculating FACT-G, 0 and 108 could be considered worst and best health states. FACT -B is used for assessment of HRQoL in participants with breast cancer. It consists of 36 items, summarized to 5 subscales: 7 items for each physical, functional, social/family; all 3 ranged from 0-28, emotional (6 items) ranged from 0-24, and breast cancer subscale (9 items) ranged from 0-36. All single-item measures ranges from 0-144. High scale score represents a better QoL.

intervention.description: 8mg/kg iv loading dose, followed by 6mg/kg iv every 3 weeks

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: The participants were randomized 1:1 using a block design randomization procedure with stratification (for prior adjuvant/neo-adjuvant taxane, trastuzumab as part of adjuvant treatment versus no trastuzumab, estrogen/progesterone receptor hormone receptor status and measurable disease) to avoid an imbalance of important prognostic factors.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 milligrams per kilogram (mg/kg) loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by docetaxel 100 milligrams per square meter (mg/m^2) on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent, and for a minimum of 6 cycles, respectively.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Bevacizumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg, bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent.

participants_list.participants: This was using a data cutoff of 30 June 2011.
This was using a data cutoff of 30 June 2011.

baseline.population: Intent-to-treat (ITT) population: All randomized participants, regardless of whether they actually received study treatment or not.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. group.description: Total of all reporting groups

outcome.title: Progression Free Survival (PFS)
outcome.description: PFS was defined as the time from randomization to time of first documented disease progression (unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions) or death, whichever occurred first as assessed by Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.0 (RECIST v1.0). Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started. Primary PFS variable was defined based on the investigators’ assessments and the statistical conclusions on the primary efficacy endpoint were based on investigator assessed PFS. PFS was estimated using Kaplan-Meier methods.

measure.title: Overall Survival (OS)
measure.description: OS was defined as the time from randomization to the date of death, regardless of the cause of death. OS was estimated using Kaplan-Meier methods.

measurement_list.measurement: The upper range of 95% confidence interval (CI) was not calculable due to immature OS data as greater than 50% of participants were censored at the time of clinical cutoff (30 June 2011).
The upper range of 95% confidence interval (CI) was not calculable due to immature OS data as greater than 50% of participants were censored at the time of clinical cutoff (30 June 2011).

outcome.title: Percentage of Participants With a Best Overall Response (OR) of Confirmed Complete Response (CR) or Partial Response (PR) in Participants With Measurable Disease at Baseline
outcome.description: Best OR was assessed using RECIST v1.0 criteria. Participants were classified as responders if their best OR was either confirmed CR (disappearance of all target lesions) or confirmed PR (at least a 30% decrease in the sum of the longest diameter [LD] of target lesions, taking as reference the baseline sum LD). Participants without any post-baseline assessments were regarded as non-responders. The 95% CI for the one sample binomial using Pearson-Clopper method.
outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)
outcome.population: ITT Population; only participants with measurable disease at baseline were included in the analysis.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent, and for a minimum of 6 cycles, respectively.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Bevacizumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg, bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent.

measure.title: Percentage of Participants With a Best Overall Response (OR) of Confirmed Complete Response (CR) or Partial Response (PR) in Participants With Measurable Disease at Baseline
measure.description: Best OR was assessed using RECIST v1.0 criteria. Participants were classified as responders if their best OR was either confirmed CR (disappearance of all target lesions) or confirmed PR (at least a 30% decrease in the sum of the longest diameter [LD] of target lesions, taking as reference the baseline sum LD). Participants without any post-baseline assessments were regarded as non-responders. The 95% CI for the one sample binomial using Pearson-Clopper method.
measure.population: ITT Population; only participants with measurable disease at baseline were included in the analysis.

analysis.estimate_desc: 95% CI for the difference in response rates using Hauck-Anderson method.

outcome.title: Duration of Response (DR)
outcome.description: DR was defined as the time when response (CR or PR per RECIST v1.0) was first documented to the date of disease progression per RECIST v1.0 (unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions) or death. Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started.
outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)
outcome.population: ITT Population: only participants with a best OR of CR or PR were included in the analysis.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent, and for a minimum of 6 cycles, respectively.

measure.title: Duration of Response (DR)
measure.description: DR was defined as the time when response (CR or PR per RECIST v1.0) was first documented to the date of disease progression per RECIST v1.0 (unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions) or death. Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started.
measure.population: ITT Population: only participants with a best OR of CR or PR were included in the analysis.

outcome.title: Time to Treatment Failure (TTF)
outcome.description: TTF was defined as the time between randomization and date of disease progression (per RECIST v1.0; unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions), death, or withdrawal of treatment due to adverse events, withdrawal of informed consent, insufficient therapeutic response, refusal of treatment/failure to co-operate, or failure to return, whichever occurred first. Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started.
outcome.time_frame: Every 9 weeks up to Week 36, thereafter every 12 weeks until disease progression (up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years)

measure.title: Time to Treatment Failure (TTF)
measure.description: TTF was defined as the time between randomization and date of disease progression (per RECIST v1.0; unequivocal progression of existing non-target lesions), death, or withdrawal of treatment due to adverse events, withdrawal of informed consent, insufficient therapeutic response, refusal of treatment/failure to co-operate, or failure to return, whichever occurred first. Progressive disease is defined using RECIST v1.0 as at least a 20% increase in the sum of the longest diameter of target lesions, taking as reference the smallest sum longest diameter recorded since the treatment started.

outcome.title: Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Generic (FACT-G) and Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Breast (FACT-B) Subscale Scores
outcome.description: FACT-G is core questionnaire of Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) measurement system to evaluate quality of life (QoL) in cancer population. FACT-G consisted of 27 questions grouped in 4 domains of general Health-Related QoL (HRQoL): Physical Well-being (PWB), Social/Family Well-Being (SWB), Emotional Well-Being (EWB) and Functional Well-Being (FWB); each ranged from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much). FACT-G ranged between 0-108. Since questions could be reversed coded, as appropriate, before calculating FACT-G, 0 and 108 could be considered worst and best health states. FACT -B is used for assessment of HRQoL in participants with breast cancer. It consists of 36 items, summarized to 5 subscales: 7 items for each physical, functional, social/family; all 3 ranged from 0-28, emotional (6 items) ranged from 0-24, and breast cancer subscale (9 items) ranged from 0-36. All single-item measures ranges from 0-144. High scale score represents a better QoL.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline, Cycles 3, 5, 11, and post progressive disease (PD; 14 to 28 days after disease progression [up to the clinical cutoff of 30 June 2011, up to 4.75 years])
outcome.population: ITT Population; n (number) = number of participants assessed for the given parameter at the specified visit.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent, and for a minimum of 6 cycles, respectively.

group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg, bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent.

measure.description: FACT-G is core questionnaire of Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy (FACIT) measurement system to evaluate quality of life (QoL) in cancer population. FACT-G consisted of 27 questions grouped in 4 domains of general Health-Related QoL (HRQoL): Physical Well-being (PWB), Social/Family Well-Being (SWB), Emotional Well-Being (EWB) and Functional Well-Being (FWB); each ranged from 0 (not at all) to 4 (very much). FACT-G ranged between 0-108. Since questions could be reversed coded, as appropriate, before calculating FACT-G, 0 and 108 could be considered worst and best health states. FACT -B is used for assessment of HRQoL in participants with breast cancer. It consists of 36 items, summarized to 5 subscales: 7 items for each physical, functional, social/family; all 3 ranged from 0-28, emotional (6 items) ranged from 0-24, and breast cancer subscale (9 items) ranged from 0-36. All single-item measures ranges from 0-144. High scale score represents a better QoL.
measure.population: ITT Population; n (number) = number of participants assessed for the given parameter at the specified visit.

reported_events.time_frame: From time of first drug intake up to 28 days after last dose study treatment (up to 4.75 years).
reported_events.desc: Safety population included all participants who had received at least 1 dose of the trial medication, whether withdrawn prematurely or not.

group.title: Trastuzumab + Docetaxel
group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent, and for a minimum of 6 cycles, respectively.

group.description: Trastuzumab 8 mg/kg loading dose administered intravenously on Day 1 of Cycle 1, followed by bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel 100 mg/m^2 on Day 2 of Cycle 1. Then a maintenance dose of trastuzumab at 6 mg/kg, bevacizumab 15 mg/kg and docetaxel at 100 mg/m^2 were administered intravenously on Day 1 of each 3-weekly cycle until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity (requiring discontinuation of study treatment), or withdrawal of participant’s consent.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The Study being conducted under this Agreement is part of the Overall Study. Investigator is free to publish in reputable journals or to present at professional conferences the results of the Study, but only after the first publication or presentation that involves the Overall Study. The Sponsor may request the Confidential Information be deleted and/or the publication be postponed in order to protect the Sponsor’s intellectual property rights.
